title-group.article-title: Effective Tax Rates as Determinants of Canadian Capital Structure

abstract.p: The hypothesis that firms subject to lower corporate tax rates use less debt has not been tested before, possibly because the statutory tax rate changes infrequently. However, the theory upon which this hypothesis is based uses tax shield substitutes for debt (depreciation and investment tax credits) at the individual firm level and, therefore, implicitly uses effective tax rates. The present study adjusts the effective tax rate to insure the one way relationship (from tax rate to debt level) explicit in the hypothesis. The hypothesis is then tested both cross-sectionally and across time at the individual firm level, using Canadian data. The results of the two sets of tests are internally consistent with each other and provide support, albeit weak, for the hypothesis. We conclude that the firm's effective tax rate has some bearing on the amount of debt it uses.

p.mixed-citation: Cordes and Sheffrin found similar results for U.S. effective tax rates [6, p. 101].
